prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
AITA for telling my friend she’s still single due to having 5 babies by different fathers?
She finished her 5th divorce two years ago, and for these two years she keeps asking me questions that also insult me.

 “How did you get a man at 30 with kids? It’s because you’re so skinny.” 

“Do I have to stop eating like you? Haha haha”

“You has so many dates. Guys only want basic blondes who are girly.”

“Did you only talk about sex with them?!”

For two years I’ve brushed off the insults, and replied: “ You’re in a small town” or “focus on yourself , and someone special will come around”

Finally she asks for the billionth time “How did you get any dates at 30 with kids?!? You don’t even have a real job! Tell me the truth- why can’t I get anyone?”

I replied honestly and said: “ You have five kids with different dads and none of them pay child support. It’s going to be hard for someone to accept that when you openly are looking for a father figure.”

This launched her into an insult fury, and she hung up on me. 

For reference: I’m not skinny but I work out (healthy weight). I eat more than her, honestly, not starving. I’m girly about some things I guess. I have two kids by the same dad and we split custody 50/50. I work in the adult industry, but only need to put in 8-10 hours a week to make a way better than average income. She keeps insulting my work even though she tried to do it, as well. I also have a vanilla job and an MBA. 

I was tired of being hit low quality and untrue insults, so I replied with what I thought was the truth.

Now, all of our mutual friends are saying I have skinny privilege and such. I’m entitled and don’t understand what she’s going through. They said it was messed up to say that and I’m a shitty friend, and I get whatever I want. She’s not going through anything that major. She’s just dating and being a mom like I had to do. 

Now I’m stuck with my mouth shut, and I’m mad at everyone because I’m not privileged or entitled at all- I’ve worked very hard for anything and everything I have.  And side note- the girl keeps talking about her

AITA for saying that? Was there a better thing to say? 
"""

I think the author is in the wrong but curious what you think.
Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, let's try to figure out if the author is in the wrong here. So, the situation is about a friend who has gone through multiple divorces and now has five kids with different fathers. The author is fed up with the friend's insults and finally tells her that her situation with the kids makes it hard to find someone. The friend gets angry, and mutual friends are blaming the author.

First, I need to consider the context. The friend has been making comments about the author's weight, job, and dating life, which the author has been brushing off. But after two years, the author confronts the friend about the root issue. The author's response was honest but maybe harsh. The question is whether that was justified.

The key points here are about friendship dynamics. Friends should ideally support each other, but the friend was being hostile. However, the author's response was direct and pointed out a sensitive issue. Even if the author felt insulted, responding with a critique of the friend's personal life might cross a line. The friend's actions (multiple children with different fathers) are personal choices, and the author's comment could be seen as judgmental, even if they believe it's the truth.

Additionally, mutual friends are reacting negatively, suggesting that the author's approach wasn't well-received. The author's friends are pointing to "skin privilege" and entitlement, implying that the author's own situation allows them to make such comments. The author's job in the adult industry and having an MBA might make their perspective different, but the way they delivered their response might have been hurtful.

The friend's behavior—insulting the author repeatedly—doesn't justify the author's response in a way that cuts to the core of the friend's choices. Even if the author was tired of the insults, the response was about the friend's life choices, which can be sensitive. The author might have had the right to set boundaries, but the method of doing so could be problematic.

In terms of better alternatives, the author could have addressed the insults without attacking the friend's personal circumstances. Maybe focusing on their own feelings rather than the friend's situation. Instead of saying "you can't find someone because of your kids," they could have said something like, "I feel uncomfortable when you make these comments about me. Let's talk about something else."

Considering all this, the author is in the wrong because the response was judgmental and potentially hurtful, even if the underlying sentiment was a reaction to provocation. Friends should communicate issues without personal attacks, especially on sensitive topics like family and relationships.
